title: Abstract Journal Colorectal Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Peritoneal metastases confer the worst survival in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer.Current management options are limited; with treatment resistance and disease progression common.The development of organoids as a pre-clinical disease model has raised the possibility of performing throughput drug screening to evaluate tumour sensitivities to drugs.In this multi-centre, prospective exploratory study, we aim to evaluate the feasibility of a novel organoid based platform to integrate genomic and functional drug sensitivities to deliver personalized therapy to patients with treatment refractory CRPM Methodology: Tumour biopsies from patients undergoing surgical intervention for CRPM were used to grow organoids.Organoids were validated before undergoing throughput drug testing against over 50 FDA approved drugs Results: Organoids were found to share over 90% genomic concordance with native tumour tissue.Against FOLFOX and FOLFIRI combination regimens, organoid drug sensitivity in-vitro largely mirrored patient responses to the same drug in-vivo, confirming the validity of this organoid-based platform.Additionally, organoid drug responses were concordant with genomic driven biomarkers.Most importantly, novel therapies were detected in many patients with treatment refractory CRPM, when no genomic driven biomarkers were present, underscoring the value of functional drug testing in providing newer treatment options for patients in this otherwise poor prognostic cohort.Conclusions: An organoid based personalized medicine platform is feasible with promising early results.A phase II clinical trial is in the process of being established to further evaluate the feasibility of this platform in a clinically timely manner.
